awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Building Human Social Networks to Develop Data-Driven Approaches that Expand Lifelong Learning Opportunities
awd_abstract_narration:
Industry demands more highly qualified graduates who can adapt to a rapidly changing work environment, while government demands higher quality in undergraduate education. These demands raise questions about how higher education institutions can meet such needs.  Unfortunately, government, industry, and higher education do not naturally come together often enough to achieve the needed student outcomes. The recent focus on ?big data? is further raising questions about how the government, industry, and higher education capture vast amounts of information about student learning.  This project will explore the intersection of big data with educational opportunities across a learner?s life, the opportunities and challenges created by these intersections, and what roles different institutions (e.g. K-12, industry, universities, government) will or should play in improving undergraduate education. Through a series of workshops, this project aims to facilitate interactions among constituents from industry, the government, and higher education institutions.  The goal is to identify the kinds of big data that can tell us how to expand learning opportunities across a student?s lifetime.  Through these workshops, participants will be guided to use big data to investigate trends in undergraduate engineering education, including:  redefining engineering education in relation to the skills needed to be a working engineer; exploring how real-time feedback can promote learning; increasing the efficiency at which engineers acquire new knowledge and skills;  understanding the interconnections across the educational systems; and rethinking the shift towards more automation, which may radically change the skills needed for employability. Big data and other trends will fundamentally change how education is obtained, who has access to various forms of education (e.g., on-line vs in person courses), and the activities that define a high-quality engineering education. By exploring the implications of big data on education, this project has the potential to transform engineering education specifically and STEM education more generally.

More specifically, this project will involve a series of four workshops that are designed to achieve the following: (1) map the engineering education ecosystem from the perspective of how the affordances created by big data will impact processes, cultures, and structures in higher education; (2) explore opportunities at productive interfaces within the ecosystem; (3) understand resource allocation and flow; and (4) develop heuristics to allow various stakeholders to navigate cultural and structural shifts. Additionally, the project will integrate data collection through ethnography and survey methodologies adapted for complex, dynamic systems to more broadly capture perspectives across engineering education and explicitly focuses on network building and disseminating materials to help various entities across engineering education navigate change. This project is designed to advance knowledge of how different sectors within the engineering education ecosystem capitalize on, adapt to, or are threatened by education and workforce trends broadly driven by big data. The workshops will draw a broad audience from many sectors, including both industry and university representatives with broad expertise, and networks of people involved in personalized learning.  Advances in information technology and the ability to monitor and analyze the interactions of millions of learners with online content has the potential to lead to transformative shifts in education. While these technologies have the capacity to create more equity and access to education, without opportunities for the range of stakeholders to communicate and build robust networks, such a transformative outcome cannot be assured. The opportunities for networking and relationship building in this project are supported scenario analysis and systems thinking, in a framework that has been shown to affect participant narratives.

por.por_cntn:
Throughout the history of the United States, technology has impacted on all aspects of citizens’ lives.  The societal changes caused by technology bring both benefits and disadvantages, and these are rarely equally distributed.  This project sought to understand how one of the large technologically-driven changes going on currently—increasing use and access to information technology for learning—will broadly impact how future engineers are educated.  The project adopted an ecology-based framework that viewed engineers’ education as a life-long process that is affected not just by schools and universities, but their employers; the opportunities available in their communities; and the types of learning, including access to on-line materials, they have access to.

To understand the current trends and possible future impacts of technology on the larger ecosystem responsible for the education of engineers, this project planned to hold four regional workshops to inform a large-scale survey.  One workshop was held before the pandemic made in-person meetings unsafe.  Following COVID-19, the project shifted to interviewing students impacted by rapid shifts to technology-based education as well as individuals working across the education-technology interface, particularly individuals from educational technology (EduTech) companies.

From the in-person workshop the project discovered three interfaces where the different sectors of the larger engineering education system fail to communicate effectively, leading to potentially less effective education.  The first of was that what constitutes ‘engineering culture’ varies between organizations, and the failure to communicate and continually reassess cultural values across interfaces leads to systemic loss that need not occur.   Second, there is a lack of shared information at the interface between traditional educational institutions and EduTech startups.  Both are highly innovative and would be strengthened by more robust collaboration.  The third interface is between ‘durable’ and ‘perishable’ knowledge.  Durable knowledge lasts while perishable knowledge becomes outdated as technology moves forward; engineers need both forms of knowledge to be successful throughout their careers.  Better communication between various sectors of the system would enable the value of different forms of knowledge to be made more explicit.

Interviews of undergraduate engineering students highlighted the importance of ‘invisible supports’ in higher education.  Invisible supports are environmental cues and structures that typically go unnoticed by students, but which they rely upon to support their learning.  These varied widely between students and institutions, and while students only noticed these supports after they went home and started remote learning,  most students self-constructed replacement support using existing on-line tools and platforms.   For example Discord (often used in on-line games) was used to create widely accessible virtual study groups.  There is an opportunity for educational institutions to improve their outcomes by understanding and enhancing such supports.

Individual interviews with engineering faculty and students, educational technology firms, and industry representatives focused on the EduTech-university interface to understand how such technology might impact education broadly.  While the perception is that an adversarial relationship exists between educators and educational technology, the reality is more nuanced.   There are four core narratives at the interface between educational institutions and EduTech:  the promise of the Digital Revolution, the concept of teachers as “dinosaurs” obstructing change, the utopia of “democratized education”, and the claim that higher education will “go the way of cable TV”.   While each of these points of engagement resonate with different groups of stakeholders, they serve as centers of conversation which can lead to improved conversations in a space where technology is changing rapidly.  It was found however, that the US is becoming somewhat of a backwater in the EdTech adoption space as companies focus on regions that have a higher probability of uptake:  Vietnam, China, India, Indonesia, the Philippines, and Singapore (VChIIPS).

In summary, this project provided a better understanding of how advances in information technology are impacting the system that educates engineers in the United States, and possible ways to make improvements to this system to address pressing issues of cost and accessibility.
